Many TV shows have adapted to the pandemic by incorporating virtual elements like Zoom calls, video chats, and other virtual communication platforms into their episodes. This has allowed for the production of new episodes while following COVID-19 safety precautions.

For example, late-night talk shows like The Tonight Show and The Late Show have transitioned to virtual shows, with celebrities joining in via video calls. Similarly, award shows like the Emmys and the Oscars have gone virtual, with nominees and presenters joining via video from their homes.

Also, some TV shows have utilized the virtual format to tell stories that reflect the reality of the pandemic. For instance, the hit sitcom Parks and Recreation released a special episode in 2020 set during the pandemic, which was produced remotely, with the characters connecting via video calls.

Overall, the pandemic has spurred innovation in the entertainment industry, forcing it to adapt and incorporate digital technologies like never before.
